title: Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits relief that Kasper Schmeichel can't be signed by Chinese Super League clubs

Claudio Ranieri has heaved a sigh of relief that the mega-money of Chinese football can’t prise Kasper Schmeichel away from Leicester. 
The Foxes’ chief celebrated the return of the great Dane to his line-up last month following Schmeichel’s recovery from a fractured hand. 
And the champions’ form has picked up with Schmeichel back – with two clean sheets in the last three outings giving rise to a belief that Leicester can break their away-day hoodoo. 
With clubs in the Chinese Super League cherry-picking the best talent, Ranieri could have been forgiven for looking over his shoulder. Schmeichel has returned to action in recent weeks after recovering from injury (Photo: Reuters) The Dane was an integral part of Leicester's title-winning side last term (Photo: Plumb Images) 
But China’s authorities have judged that their country is so lacking in quality­­goalkeepers that they have banned any imports – ­preferring instead to nurture their own talent. 
And, following Leonardo Ulloa’s decision to hand in a transfer request last week, that has given Ranieri one less issue to worry about. 
He said: “We wouldn’t be selling Kasper in this market – but obviously it helps if China cannot buy him. 
“They are buying players. A lot of young players. If their government wants that, it will happen. 
“At the beginning, they were going after all players. Now they’re starting to get medium players at the age of 26, 27– and it could be a big problem for all of us in the Premier League. Ranieri is bidding to steer his team clear of relegation danger (Photo: Plumb Images) 
“So, I am happy they cannot try to buy him because he is one of the best keepers around today. Good, solid, excellent mentality. 
“I like that he records all of his training sessions. He wants to look at all of the goals we concede. He wants to see what happened, where his position was, if he could improve it. 
“And when Kasper broke his hand, of course we missed him. I miss all of the players when they have done so well.” 
Ranieri’s season has been a bumpy ride so far.
